Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Longview Energy Exchange, LLC; Notice of preliminary permit application accepted for filing and soliciting comments, motions to intervene, and competing applications
Abstract: On 1/3/2012, Longview Energy Exchange LLC filed an application for a preliminary permit, pursuant to section 4(f) of the Federal Power Act, proposing to study the feasibility of the Longview Pumped Storage Project to be located Ash Fork City, Yavapai County, AZ. The proposed project would consist of two upper reservoirs constructed of rock fill each with a dam drainage system; a single lower reservoir dam constructed of earth fill materials with an internal dam drainage system; a reinforced concrete powerhouse containing six units; a switchyard to be located near the powerhouse; a transmission line extending from the project to an interconnection with the existing Arizona Public Service owned and operated Eldorado-Moenkopi 500-kv line; a transmission line extending from the project to an interconnection with an existing Western Area Power Administration owned and operated 230-kv; and appurtenant facilities. The estimated generation of the Longview Pumped Storage Project would be 35,040 Gw-hr/yr. The deadline for filing comments, motions to intervene, competing applications (without notices of intent), or notices of intent to file competing applications is 60 days from the issuance date (1/12/2012) of this notice.

Authors: Rodger E.J., Suetani R.J., Jones G.T., Kleffmann T., Carne A., Legge M., McCormick S.P.A.
Title: Proteomic analysis of aortae from human lipoprotein(a) transgenic mice shows an early metabolic response independent of atherosclerosis
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Centre for Protein Research, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Rodger, E.J., Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Suetani, R.J., Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Jones, G.T., Department of Surgical Sciences, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Kleffmann, T., Centre for Protein Research, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Carne, A., Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Legge, M., Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; McCormick, S.P.A., Department of Biochemistry, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand
Abstract: Background: Elevated low density lipoprotein (LDL) and lipoprotein(a) are independent risk factors for the development of atherosclerosis. Using a proteomic approach we aimed to determine early changes in arterial protein expression in transgenic mice containing both human LDL and lipoprotein(a) in circulation. Methods and Results: Plasma lipid analyses showed the lipoprotein(a) transgenic mice had significantly higher lipid levels than wildtype, including a much increased LDL and high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Analysis of aortae from lipoprotein(a) mice showed lipoprotein(a) accumulation but no lipid accumulation or foam cells, leaving the arteries essentially atherosclerosis free. Using two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and mass spectrometry, we identified 34 arterial proteins with significantly altered abundance (P<0.05) in lipoprotein(a) transgenic mice compared to wildtype including 17 that showed a ≥2 fold difference. Some proteins of interest showed a similarly altered abundance at the transcript level. These changes collectively indicated an initial metabolic response that included a down regulation in energy, redox and lipid metabolism proteins and changes in structural proteins at a stage when atherosclerosis had not yet developed. Conclusions: Our study shows that human LDL and lipoprotein(a) promote changes in the expression of a unique set of arterial proteins which may be early indicators of the metabolic disturbances preceding atherosclerosis. © 2012 Rodger et al.

Authors: Giljarhus K.E.T., Munkejord S.T., Skaugen G.
Title: Solution of the Span-Wagner equation of state using a density-energy state function for fluid-dynamic simulation of carbon dioxide
Affiliations: SINTEF Energy Research, P.O. Box 4761 Sluppen, NO-7465 Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Giljarhus, K.E.T., SINTEF Energy Research, P.O. Box 4761 Sluppen, NO-7465 Trondheim, Norway; Munkejord, S.T., SINTEF Energy Research, P.O. Box 4761 Sluppen, NO-7465 Trondheim, Norway; Skaugen, G., SINTEF Energy Research, P.O. Box 4761 Sluppen, NO-7465 Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: With the introduction of carbon capture and storage (CCS) as a means to reduce carbon emissions, a need has arisen for accurate and efficient simulation tools. In this work, we propose a method for dynamic simulations of carbon dioxide using the Span-Wagner reference equation of state. The simulations are based on using the density and internal energy as states, which is a formulation naturally resulting from mass and energy balances. The proposed numerical method uses information about saturation lines to choose between single-phase and two-phase equation systems, and is capable of handling phase transitions. To illustrate the potential of the method, it is applied to simulations of tank depressurization, and to fluid-dynamic simulations of pipe transport. © 2011 American Chemical Society.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revising underground storage tank regulations-revisions to existing requirements and new requirements for secondary containment and operator training
Abstract: The EPA is extending the public comment period for the proposed changes to the 1988 UST technical, financial responsibility, and state program approval regulations published in the Federal Register on 11/18/2011. These changes establish federal requirements that are similar to key portions of the Energy Policy Act of 2005; they also update certain 1988 UST regulations. The proposed changes include adding secondary containment requirements for new and replaced tanks and piping; adding operator training requirements; adding periodic operation and maintenance requirements for UST systems; removing certain deferrals; adding new release prevention and detection technologies; updating codes of practice; making editorial and technical corrections; and updating state program approval requirements to incorporate these new changes. These changes will likely protect human health and the environment by increasing the number of prevented UST releases and quickly detecting them, if they occur. This document extends the comment period for 60 days, from 2/16/2012 until 4/16/2012. Comments must be received on or before 4/16/2012. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 280 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, confidential business information, groundwater, hazardous materials, petroleum, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, UST, water pollution control, and water supply. Subjects in 40 CFR Part 281 include environmental protection, administrative practice and procedures, hazardous materials, petroleum, state program approval, and UST.

Authors: Pistor V., Ornaghi F.G., Ornaghi H.L., Zattera A.J.
Title: Dynamic mechanical characterization of epoxy/epoxycyclohexyl-POSS nanocomposites
Affiliations: Laboratory of Advanced Polymers, Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS), Caxias do Sul, RS, Brazil; PPGEM, Laboratory of Composite Materials (LACOMP), Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS), Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil; Laboratory of Polymers, Center of Exact Sciences and Technology (CCET), Caxias do Sul University (UCS), Caxias do Sul, RS, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Pistor, V., Laboratory of Advanced Polymers, Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS), Caxias do Sul, RS, Brazil; Ornaghi, F.G., Laboratory of Advanced Polymers, Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS), Caxias do Sul, RS, Brazil; Ornaghi, H.L., PPGEM, Laboratory of Composite Materials (LACOMP), Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (UFRGS), Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil; Zattera, A.J., Laboratory of Polymers, Center of Exact Sciences and Technology (CCET), Caxias do Sul University (UCS), Caxias do Sul, RS, Brazil
Abstract: In this study, an epoxy matrix containing 1, 2 and 5% of a polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane (POSS) was analyzed by dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) in isothermal and non-isothermal runs in order to evaluate the interactions between the epoxy/POSS systems obtained. Non-isothermal DMA curves showed that, upon POSS addiction, the storage modulus in the rubbery region (E r) and the loss modulus decrease due changes caused in the average crosslink densities in the epoxy/POSS systems. The glass transition temperature (T g) keep the same trend for all nanocomposites studied and there was higher activation energy (E a) values with the incorporation of the nanofiller due an enhancement in the cohesive energy density. Through isothermal DMA curves studied, it is noted an increase in the Kauzmann temperature and the fragility concept proposed by Angell upon POSS addiction, suggesting a formation of a kinetically weaker system. © 2011 Elsevier B.V.

Authors: Berg T., Singh J., Hardacre A., Boland M.J.
Title: The role of cotyledon cell structure during in vitro digestion of starch in navy beans
Affiliations: Riddet Institute, Massey University, Private Bag 11 222, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand; Institute of Food Nutrition and Human Health, Massey University, Private Bag 11 222, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Berg, T., Riddet Institute, Massey University, Private Bag 11 222, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand; Singh, J., Riddet Institute, Massey University, Private Bag 11 222, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand; Hardacre, A., Institute of Food Nutrition and Human Health, Massey University, Private Bag 11 222, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand; Boland, M.J., Riddet Institute, Massey University, Private Bag 11 222, Palmerston North 4442, New Zealand
Abstract: Studies on the physico-chemical, microstructural characteristics and in vitro (under simulated gastric and small intestine conditions) starch digestibility of navy beans were carried out. The microstructure of raw and cooked beans observed through scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed the presence of hexagonal or angular shaped cotyledon cells (50-100 μm size) containing starch granules with a size ranging between 10 and 50 μm. The extent of starch hydrolysis (%) after 120 min of in vitro gastro-intestinal digestion differed between whole navy beans (∼60%) and milled bean flour and bean starch (85-90%) after they were cooked under similar conditions. Starch hydrolysis (%) increased significantly when the cotyledon cells in the cooked whole navy beans were disrupted using high pressure treatment (French press). The storage of freshly cooked whole beans resulted in a lower (40-45%) starch hydrolysis whereas re-heating increased the same to 70-80% during in vitro small intestinal digestion. The SEM pictures of cooked navy bean digesta after different intervals of in vitro gastric and small intestinal digestion showed that the cotyledon cell structure is maintained well throughout the digestion period. However cotyledon cells appear shrunken and developed wrinkles during in vitro digestion. Particle size analysis of cooked bean paste taken before and after the in vitro gastro-intestinal digestion showed similar particle size distributions. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The international consortium of energy managers; Notice of preliminary permit application accepted for filing and soliciting comments, motions to intervene, and competing applications
Abstract: On 1/6/2012, The International Consortium of Energy Managers filed an application, pursuant to section 4(f) of the Federal Power Act, proposing to study the feasibility of the Blue Diamond Pumped Storage Project to be located in Clark County, NV. The proposed project would be closed loop and would not be located on any existing water body. The proposed project would consist of a new embankment creating an upper reservoir with a maximum elevation of 4810 ft above msl, and a storage capacity of 4900 acre-ft; a new embankment creating a lower reservoir with a maximum elevation of 3320 ft msl, and a storage capacity of 4900 acre-ft; a concrete and steel penstock; a powerhouse containing two pump/turbine units with a total installed capacity of 450 Mw; a transmission line; and appurtenant facilities. The proposed project would produce ∼ 4500 Mw-hr/day of energy, and use about 5600 Mw-hr/day to pump water from the lower to the upper reservoir. Deadline for filing motions to intervene and protests, comments, recommendations, preliminary terms and conditions, and preliminary prescriptions is 60 days from the issuance date (2/8/2012) of this notice.

Authors: Mhike W., Focke W.W., Mofokeng J.P., Luyt A.S.
Title: Thermally conductive phase-change materials for energy storage based on low-density polyethylene, soft Fischer-Tropsch wax and graphite
Affiliations: Institute for Applied Materials, University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0002, South Africa; Department of Chemistry, University of the Free State (Qwaqwa Campus), Private Bag X13, Phuthaditjhaba 9866, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Mhike, W., Institute for Applied Materials, University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0002, South Africa; Focke, W.W., Institute for Applied Materials, University of Pretoria, Pretoria 0002, South Africa; Mofokeng, J.P., Department of Chemistry, University of the Free State (Qwaqwa Campus), Private Bag X13, Phuthaditjhaba 9866, South Africa; Luyt, A.S., Department of Chemistry, University of the Free State (Qwaqwa Campus), Private Bag X13, Phuthaditjhaba 9866, South Africa
Abstract: Phase change materials based on graphite-filled wax/polyethylene blends could find application as thermal energy storage materials. Such compounds, comprising wax to polyethylene in a 3:2 proportion, were prepared by twin screw compounding. Two types of graphite were used in an attempt to improve the thermal conductivity of the compounds. Expanded graphite enhanced the thermal conductivity by more than 200% at a loading of 10 wt.%, compared to a ca. 60% improvement with natural graphite flakes at the same loading. The TGA results showed that all the compounds underwent a two-step degradation. In all cases the mass % ratios of the two degradation steps were roughly 3:2 for wax:LDPE, which confirms that the wax evaporated completely before the degradation of LDPE started. The DSC results suggest that the heat energy storing capacity of the wax is not influenced by the other components as long as heating is restricted to temperatures just above the melting point of the wax. It is also apparent that the presence of both forms of graphite enhanced the rate of heat transfer to the PCMs. The DMA results show that the presence of wax had a softening effect, while the presence of graphite opposed this softening effect by reinforcing the PCM composites. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Köfeler H.C., Fauland A., Rechberger G.N., Trötzmüller M.
Title: Mass spectrometry based lipidomics: An overview of technological platforms
Affiliations: Core Facility for Mass Spectrometry, Medical University of Graz, Stiftingtalstrasse 24, 8010 Graz, Austria; Institute of Analytical Chemistry and Food Chemistry, Graz University of Technology, Stremayrgasse 9/II, 8010 Graz, Austria; Department for Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Humboldtstrasse 50/II, 8010 Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Köfeler, H.C., Core Facility for Mass Spectrometry, Medical University of Graz, Stiftingtalstrasse 24, 8010 Graz, Austria; Fauland, A., Institute of Analytical Chemistry and Food Chemistry, Graz University of Technology, Stremayrgasse 9/II, 8010 Graz, Austria; Rechberger, G.N., Department for Molecular Biosciences, University of Graz, Humboldtstrasse 50/II, 8010 Graz, Austria; Trötzmüller, M., Core Facility for Mass Spectrometry, Medical University of Graz, Stiftingtalstrasse 24, 8010 Graz, Austria
Abstract: One decade after the genomic and the proteomic life science revolution, new 'omics' fields are emerging. The metabolome encompasses the entity of small molecules- Most often end products of a catalytic process regulated by genes and proteins-with the lipidome being its fat soluble subdivision. Within recent years, lipids are more and more regarded not only as energy storage compounds but also as interactive players in various cellular regulation cycles and thus attain rising interest in the bio-medical community. The field of lipidomics is, on one hand, fuelled by analytical technology advances, particularly mass spectrometry and chromatography, but on the other hand new biological questions also drive analytical technology developments. Compared to fairly standardized genomic or proteomic high-throughput protocols, the high degree of molecular heterogeneity adds a special analytical challenge to lipidomic analysis. In this review, we will take a closer look at various mass spectrometric platforms for lipidomic analysis. We will focus on the advantages and limitations of various experimental setups like 'shotgun lipidomics', liquid chromatography-Mass spectrometry (LC-MS) and matrix assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight (MALDI-TOF) based approaches. We will also examine available software packages for data analysis, which nowadays is in fact the rate limiting step for most 'omics' workflows. © 2012 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.

Authors: Glinka T., Glinka M.
Title: Variants of the wind turbines solutions [Warianty rozwiazania elektrowni wiatrowej]
Affiliations: Politechnika Ślaska, Instytut Elektrotechniki i Informatyki, Zakład Maszyn Elektrycznych i, Inzynierii Elektrycznej w Transporcie, ul. Akademicka 10, 44-100 Gliwice, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Glinka, T., Politechnika Ślaska, Instytut Elektrotechniki i Informatyki, Zakład Maszyn Elektrycznych i, Inzynierii Elektrycznej w Transporcie, ul. Akademicka 10, 44-100 Gliwice, Poland; Glinka, M., Politechnika Ślaska, Instytut Elektrotechniki i Informatyki, Zakład Maszyn Elektrycznych i, Inzynierii Elektrycznej w Transporcie, ul. Akademicka 10, 44-100 Gliwice, Poland
Abstract: This article presents variant solutions of the energy path of the wind farm. The components that determine the economic side of the farm were discussed, that is, construction costs and the amount of energy produced. Primary energy of the wind, and the classic model of the energy path of the wind farm, determine the effectiveness of the plant. From the theory of wind energy we know that from the area encompassed by the spinning turbine blades a maximum of 38% of total wind energy may be recovered. Five different types of turbines were discussed. The best performance is exhibited by triple-blade turbine with horizontal axis. The turbine shaft is coupled with electric generator through a mechanical gearbox. Seven types of electric generators were also characterized, according to the criteria such as investment costs, rated power, reliability, operating and maintenance costs. This comparison favors two solutions: asynchronous generator with squirrel cage rotor, connected directly to the grid, and synchronous generator excited by permanent magnets. Finally, two solutions of the power collection from the wind farm were proposed, based on its cooperation with the pumped-storage power plant.
Author Keywords: Economics of wind turbine; Energy collection; Wind turbine; Wind turbine generator wtg

Authors: Kivelä R., Henniges U., Sontag-Strohm T., Potthast A.
Title: Oxidation of oat β-glucan in aqueous solutions during processing
Affiliations: Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 66, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland; Department of Chemistry, University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Kivelä, R., Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 66, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland; Henniges, U., Department of Chemistry, University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences, Vienna, Austria; Sontag-Strohm, T., Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 66, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland; Potthast, A., Department of Chemistry, University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The study investigated carbonyl group formation along the chain and the chain cleavage of cereal β-glucan during heat treatments, high pressure homogenisation, cold storage and ascorbic acid treatment of aqueous solutions of this soluble dietary fibre. The carbonyl group content and its distribution along the chain were simultaneously determined with the chain cleavage using a HPSEC/labelling method, originally developed for water-insoluble cellulose. Ascorbic acid treatment resulted in a relatively high degree of carbonyl content and extensive degradation of β-glucan, even in concentrations typically found in foods. The thermal oxidation of the β-glucan was considerable at 120 °C in a β-glucan solution with co-extracted compounds from oat ingredient, and in the highly purified solutions in presence of ferrous ions. Oxidation also probably contributed to the molecular properties during high pressure homogenisation, even thou the main degradation mechanism is the hydrolysis caused by mechanical energy. In addition to the cleavage of the β-glucan chain, the formation of compact, high molar mass species or molecule clusters were obtained in the study after ascorbic acid, heat (120 °C) and homogenisation treatments. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: β-Glucan; Ascorbic acid; Heating; High pressure homogenisation; Oxidation
Index Keywords: Ascorbic acids; Carbonyl groups; Degradation mechanism; Ferrous ion; High pressure; High pressure homogenisation; Homogenisation; Mechanical energies; Molecular properties; Molecule-clusters; Soluble dietary fibre; Thermal oxidation; Carbonylation; Cold storage; Degradation; Ketones; Mechanical properties; Organic acids; Solutions; Water content; Oxidation

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 1st International Conference on Emerging Trends in Science, Engineering and Technology, INCOSET 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 75 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Emerging Trends in Science, Engineering and Technology. The topics include: Augmentation of heat transfer and pressure drop characteristics inside a double pipe u-tube heat exchanger by using twisted tape inserts; design of integrated r134a vapor compression heating and cooling cycle; effect of thermal barrier coating on di diesel engine fuelled with p20 biodiesel; effects of compression ratio on the performance and emission characteristics of diesel engine fuelled with ethanol blended diesel fuel; green carrier; implementation of ansys for analyzing windmill tower with aisi 302 stainless steel; integration of libr-h2o vapor absorption refrigeration cycle and power cycle; implementation of methanol as fuel in si engine for the measurement of formaldehyde emission; performance characteristics of diesel engine operating with preheated palm biodiesel; recent trends in development of hydraulic press for damper flap notching; theoretical analysis of overall heat loss coefficient in a flat plate solar collector with an in-built energy storage using a phase change material; design and development of nonautomatic tabletop mini lathe; experimental analysis of the pressure distribution on different models of carbody in the windtunnel; neuro-genetic hybrid system for 2d fixture layout; basic properties and performance of vegetable oil-based boric acid nanofluids in machining; cuckoo search algorithm for optimization of sequence in pcb holes drilling process; efficient cooling of building using phaschange materials along with coolant; fatigue damage mechanisms in fiber reinforced with al2o3 composites under cyclic reversed loading; investigation of micromachining on cnc.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Gloomy economic outlook weighs on oil
Abstract: Oil markets fell due to the ongoing European debt crisis which could result in Greece leaving the euro. Oil prices also fell due to apparent progress in Iran nuclear talks. The International Atomic Energy Agency signed an accord with Tehran to allow nuclear inspectors into the country, which eased concerns about fresh conflicts in the region. Western sanctions against Iran have resulted in oil exports to ∼ 1.5 million bpd compared with ∼ 22.2 million bpd in 2011. Iranian tankers are estimated to hold ∼ 36 million bbl of oil in floating storage. The spread between Brent and WTI also narrowed due to the start of the US Seaway pipeline reversal on 5/17/2012. The pipe will initially deliver 150,000 bpd of crude from Oklahoma to Freeport on the Gulf coast, relieving some of the bottleneck at Cushing.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: INGAA study examines economic benefits of midstream infrastructure development through 2035
Abstract: According to a report from the INGAA Foundation, midstream investments from 2012-2035 to accommodate natural gas, oil, and NGL resource development will require more than $200 billion. The report highlights the economic benefits of constructing, operating, and maintaining the midstream infrastructure needed to transport domestic energy. It is based on data compiled in the INGAA Foundation's "North American Midstream Infrastructure through 2035 - A Secure Energy Future" study completed by ICF International in 2011. On average, 2000 mi of new natural gas transmission lines and laterals are anticipated to be added each year through 2035 in combination with > 200,000 hp of compression, 24 bcf of gas storage capacity, and 1.3 bcf/day of annual processing capacity additions. An additional 1300 mi of oil and NGL transmission pipelines would also be constructed each year, on average.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Nustar invests $365 million at St. James crude terminal
Abstract: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal and NuStar Energy CEO Curt Anastasio announced a $365 million capital investment by NuStar that will expand the firm's St James Terminal, creating 32 new direct jobs at the facility and an estimated 269 new indirect jobs in southeast Louisiana. The project will increase NuStar's tank storage capacity at the Mississippi River site from 8 million to 11 million bbl. Combined with earlier investments by NuStar and future expansion plans at the site, the company expects to spend $505 million on capital improvement projects at the St James Terminal over a 5-yr period.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: North America leads race to CCS
Abstract: The US and Canada are leading in developing a large-scale CCS project, according to a report from Bloomberg New Energy Finance (BNEF). It ranks Air Products' Port Arthur demonstration plant in Texas as the most advance in the world, followed by the Boundary Dam power plant in Saskatchewan, Canada. Europe's highest-placed project is Eon's plan to capture 1.1 million ton/yr of CO2 from the coal-fired Maasvlakte plant in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. BNEF credited much of North America's lead on the technology to favorable economics and government support, saying that "US and Canadian projects benefit from more public funding, lower storage costs and more options for EOR than those elsewhere". Eight of the projects are predicted to come online over the next 5 yr, > 50% of which are based in North America. Between them, they will have the capacity to inject more than 16.8 million ton/yr of CO2. To get on BNEF's list, a project must have a capacity of ≥ 1 million ton/yr, which disqualifies Norway's newly-opened Mongstad pilot facility, which has a capacity of 100,000 ton/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Confidence cited in Asia's gas infrastructure
Abstract: A poll of delegates at the World Gas Conference indicated that industry professionals are confident Asia is well-placed to support continuing growth in gas consumption through the provision of the infrastructure it needs. A total of 71% of participants thought that the region has the technical foundation to develop the systems needed to support an increased dependence on gas, while 29% of participants felt that it does not. The Industry Snapshot Poll was conducted by GL Noble Denton. A discussion on the poll results covers the Asia/Pacific region, which experienced the world's strongest increase in gas utilization in 2009; Japan's dependence on LNG in the next decade; China as the world's largest shale-gas producer by 2030; future of pipelines and storage; technological and policy advancements; the hydrogen economy, with emphasis on the use of gas pipeline systems as the natural delivery system for hydrogen; role of LNG and how LNG assets are another key enabler toward a sustainable energy future; and investment trends.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: For sale: World war II oil pipeline
Abstract: An underground network of pipelines, which kept Britain's World War II effort well-oiled could be privatized as part of plans to modernize the UK's energy infrastructure. Ownership of the Government Pipeline and Storage System could be transferred to the private sector, according to international legal firm Pinsent Masons. The network has been expanded and restructured over several decades and includes some 2500 km of cross country pipelines, storage depots, pumping stations, and other facilities. The move was announced as part of a package of measures, which will lead to the biggest shakeup of the UK energy market since privatization.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Centerpoint seeks Perryville hub trading point
Abstract: CenterPoint Energy Gas Transmission Co LLC has filed with the FERC to amend certain provisions in its tariff to establish a Perryville Hub Trading Point (PTP) within the existing Perryville Hub that can be accessed for primary or secondary receipt and/or delivery of natural gas using the company's firm and interruptible transportation and wheeling services. The PTP will have access to receive or deliver natural gas from the 21 interconnects CEGT has with interstate pipelines in the Perryville Hub. CEGT also proposes to establish the PTP as a site for trading or title transfers of natural gas between the company's shippers and/or non-shippers. In 2013, the PVH will directly connect with the high deliverability of the 7 bcf Perryville Gas Storage project, further increasing liquidity and creating additional opportunities for CEGT and its affiliate, Mississippi River Transmission's, customers.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Kinder Morgan signs processing services and storage deal
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners and BP North America have concluded a long-term commercial agreement to provide BP condensate processing services and storage at Kinder Morgan's terminals located on the Houston Ship Channel. BP has committed over 40,000 bpd of throughput at Kinder Morgan's petroleum condensate facility, which will split condensate into various components, e.g., light and heavy naphtha, kerosene, and gas oil. The $200 million facility has been designed to provide future processing expansions ≤ 100,000 bpd throughput. BP also will lease an additional 750,000 bbl of storage for Kinder Morgan's Galena Park terminal. The new storage tanks and condensate facility are expected to be in service in early 2014.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: North America: World's first oil sands CCS project
Abstract: Shell will go ahead with the first carbon capture and storage (CCS) project for an oil sands operation in Canada. The Quest project will be built on behalf of the Athabasca Oil Sands Project joint venture owners (Shell, Chevron, and Marathon Oil) and with support from the Governments of Canada and Alberta. The Athabasca Oil Sands project produces bitumen, which is piped to Shell's Scotford Upgrader near Edmonton, Alberta. From late 2015, Quest will capture and store deep underground > 1 million ton/yr of CO2 produced in bitumen processing. Quest will reduce direct emissions from the Scotford Upgrader by ≤ 35%. Both the Canadian federal and Albertan provincial governments have identified CCS as an important technology in their strategies to reduce CO2 emissions. The Alberta government will invest $745 million in Quest, while the Government of Canada will invest $120 million. The International Energy Agency calls CCS "a crucial part of worldwide efforts to limit global warming" and estimates that it could deliver ∼ one-fifth of necessary worldwide reductions in greenhouse gases by 2050. Shell is also working with governments and experts to help the development of CCS in other countries, including projects in Norway and Australia.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Kinder Morgan and BP North America enter into long-term agreements
Abstract: On 7/19/2012, Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP and BP North America completed long-term commercial agreements to provide BP condensate processing services and storage at Kinder Morgan's terminals located on the Houston Ship Channel. BP has committed over 40,000 bpd of throughput at Kinder Morgan's petroleum condensate facility, which will split condensate into various components, e.g., light and heavy naphthas, kerosene, and gas oil. The ≈ $200 million facility was designed to provide future processing expansions ≤ 100,000 bpd throughput. BP will also lease an additional 750,000 bbl of storage that Kinder Morgan will add at its Galena Park terminal. The expansion is part of Kinder Morgan's ≈ $75 million investment to construct five tanks that will connect to its condensate facility with new piping, manifolds, and pumps. The company expects the new storage tanks and condensate facility to be in service in the first quarter of 2014.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: FLRSU debuts
Abstract: Pacific Rubiales Energy Corp has signed an agreement with EXMAR NV for natural gas/LNG liquefaction, regasification, storage, and loading services agreement with Belgium-based EXMAR NV. Under the agreement, EXMAR will build, operate, and maintain a Floating Liquefaction Regasification and Storage Unit (FLRSU) to be located on the Colombian Caribbean coast. The FLRSU will have a storage capacity of 14,000 cu m of LNG and will be able to accommodate a 140,000 cu m LNG Floating Storage Unit alongside. Commercial operation of the FLRSU is expected to start in the fourth quarter of 2014.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Commonwealth pipeline to serve Marcellus and Utica shale plays
Abstract: UGI Energy Services Inc and Capitol Energy Ventures Corp have completed binding precedent agreements for firm transportation capacity on Commonwealth Pipeline. These anchor shippers have agreed to buy firm transportation capacity on the Commonwealth Pipeline for a 10-yr period at negotiated rates. Commonwealth Pipeline will provide a direct, cost-effective path for bringing natural gas produced in the Marcellus and Utica Shale plays to growing markets in central and southeastern Pennsylvania and the greater Mid-Atlantic region. The planned interstate pipeline will consist initially of 120 mi of 30-in. pipeline extending from the southern terminus of the Inergy Midstream's MARC I Pipeline in Lycoming County, PA, to several points of interconnection in southeastern Pennsylvania with other interstate pipelines, including NiSource Gas Transmission and Storage, Texas Eastern Transmission, Transco Pipeline, and Eastern Shore Natural Gas Co. Commonwealth Pipeline is also expected to connect with UGI Energy Service's natural gas liquefaction, vaporization, and storage facility near Temple, PA, and to run near or connect with multiple natural gas distribution systems in southeastern Pennsylvania. The pipeline is expected to have an initial capacity of 800,000 Dtherm/day. The project sponsors begun field work, including requesting survey permission from landowners. They anticipate filing with the FERC in early 2013 and placing the pipeline into commercial service in 2015.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Blackstone to invest $2 billion for Sabine pass liquefaction project
Abstract: Cheniere Energy Partners LP has entered into an arrangement with Blackstone Energy Partners LP, Blackstone Capital Partners VI LP, and certain affiliates in which Blackstone would provide financing worth $2 billion to fund the equity portion of the costs of developing, constructing, and placing into service its Sabine Pass liquefaction project being developed at the Sabine Pass LNG terminal, the purchase of the Creole Trail pipeline from Cheniere Energy Inc, and other partnership business purposes. Cheniere Partners is moving toward a final investment decision for development and construction of the first two of four liquefaction trains. The debt financing for the Liquefaction Project is expected to be completed shortly with construction starting in the first half of 2012. The purchase of the Creole Trail pipeline is expected to close concurrently with the closing of the financing. The Sabine Pass terminal has regasification and send-out capacity of 4 bcf/day and storage capacity of 16.9 bcfe. Cheniere Partners is developing a project to add liquefaction and export capabilities to the existing infrastructure at the Sabine Pass LNG terminal. The Liquefaction Project is being designed and permitted for up to four modular LNG trains, each with a nominal capacity of 4.5 mton/yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Why hasn't Iran spiked the oil market?
Abstract: Iran's oil is currently on its way down, even though global demand for crude is higher in 2012 than when Libya's output was shut in. The EU embargo is biting and the US Congress added another slew of sanctions to ones it has already imposed. According to Goldman Sachs, a lot of oil - as much as was lost in 2011 from Libya - could be removed from the market. Far greater volumes would also be lost if Iran did what some of its politicians say it will, and shut down the Strait of Hormuz, through which about a fifth of the world's oil passes. In June 2012, Iran told Opec that its production in May 2012 increased to 3.76 million bpd. Secondary sources guessed that the figure was closer to 3.2 million bpd. In July 2012, those secondary sources thought production had fallen again to 2.963 million bpd, according to OPEC. However, despite the fears of Goldman Sachs and others, the International Energy Agency (IEA) says the data that is available do not support rumors of a drop in the country's sales in June 2012. Due to renewed buying by China, total imports of Iranian oil around the world may have risen by > 500,000 bpd to 1.95 million bpd. At the same time, Iran's floating storage now amounts to 42 million bbl. The IEA expects non-Opec production to increase by 400,000 bpd in 2012. Production in the fourth quarter of 53.7 million bpd will be 900,000 bpd higher than it averaged in 2011. In 2013, it will increase by another 600,000 bpd.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Semgroup and gavilon increase ownership of glass mountain pipeline
Abstract: SemGroup Corp and Gavilon LLC have completed acquisition of a 25% share of Glass Mountain Pipeline LLC, previously owned by an affiliate of Chesapeake Energy Corp. SemGroup now owns 50% percent of Glass Mountain Pipeline. The remaining 50% is owned by Gavilon. Chesapeake will maintain its long-term transportation agreement with Glass Mountain Pipeline, providing the economic incentive for its construction. The Glass Mountain Pipeline will have initial capacity of 140,000 bpd of oil and 440,000 bbl of intermediate storage. It will consist of two laterals, i.e., one will originate near the town of Alva in Woods County, OK, and the second will originate near the town of Arnett in Ellis County, OK. The pipeline will increase in diameter where the laterals intersect near Cleo Springs in Major County, OK, and continue east to Cushing, OK. The pipeline will terminate at Gavilon's Cushing facility, where the joint venture will own 1 million bbl of crude oil storage.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: China tops up its tanks
Abstract: China's escalating dependence on oil imports has spurred the country to pursue a strategic stockpiling program that is expected to be a feature of the global oil market throughout this decade. Energy security is driving the nation's strategy as it seeks to cushion the blow of potential supply disruptions from the major oil producing regions of the Middle East and Africa. Aside from supply-cut insurance, the strategic petroleum reserve (SPR), which is operated by national oil firms, could also to a lesser extent be used unofficially for price smoothing. The first phase of China's SPR was run strictly as an emergency storage. The SPR plan is broken into three phases with a total capacity target of ≈ 500 million bbl. By 2020, crude imports would have jumped by 70% from 2011. As result, China's SPR in 2020 will be equivalent to ≈ 55 days of net-imports, which is less than public stocks held by the developed Asia Pacific economies.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Crosstex energy expands riverside fractionation facility
Abstract: Crosstex Energy LP is increasing its capacity to transload crude oil from rail cars to barges and pipelines at its Riverside fractionation facility in southern Louisiana from 4500 to 14,500 bpd. Construction of the Phase II expansion project at Riverside, located on the Mississippi River, will be operational in early 2013. The Phase II development at Riverside will include new storage tank facilities, upgraded pipeline connections, and improved barge delivery capabilities on the Mississippi River. The expansion project is expected to cost $16 million.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Asia and Australasia: China
Abstract: China National Offshore Oil Corp (CNOOC) is primed to construct a new 4 million ton/yr LNG import terminal at Shenzhen city in Guangdong province after the central government approved the scheme. The actual receiving capacity could be much higher as it will incorporate eight storage tanks, each with 160,000 cu m of holding space. The plant will be jointly funded and built by CNOOC on a 70% interest and Shenzhen Energy with a 30% stake. Meanwhile, CNOOC started building its second LNG terminal in Guangdong province at Jieyang city in April 2012. The 2 million ton/yr unit is due for completion in 2014. When the two terminals come online in 2015, CNOOC, along with its existing unit at Dapeng, will be able to supply ≤ 10 million ton/yr of LNG to Guangdong.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: NiSource plans 1,000-mile pipeline modernization project
Abstract: According to DOT Secretary Ray LaHood, the agency will lead the effort to help expedite federal permitting for a 1000-mi pipeline modernization project by NiSource Inc, which will produce thousands of jobs, enhance safety, and increase energy capacity. NiSource Inc will modernize its Columbia Gas Transmission LLC gas transmission and storage system by replacing aging infrastructure that serves communities in six states, including the Marcellus shale gas production region, where the majority of the pipeline infrastructure is > 40 yr old and running on inefficient platforms. The modernization project will invest $4 billion over 10-15 yr beginning in 2012. It will replace 1000 mi of large-diameter pipeline using domestic-made steel.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Excelerate energy wins permission to export LNG
Abstract: The DOE has given Excelerate Energy a long-term, multi-contract authorization to export LNG to free trade agreement nations from its Lavaca Bay LNG project, currently under development. The company will be authorized to export ≤ 10 million ton/yr of LNG produced from domestic resources for a 20-yr term commencing on the date of its first export. Located on the Texas Gulf Coast, Lavaca Bay LNG will be the first floating liquefaction export facility in the US and will utilize Excelerate's Floating Liquefaction Storage Offloading vessel technology. Excelerate will begin the FERC pre-filing process in the fourth quarter of 2012 and the facility is expected to operate in 2017.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Midstream developers busy building pipelines
Abstract: Midstream spent an estimated $755.1 million in 2011 for the development and construction of the pipeline needed to move the products produced in the Eagle Ford Shale region to the refineries and processing plants located in close areas. These construction activities resulted in close to $1.1 billion in total output impact and > $494 million in total gross regional product impact. NuStar Energy has been involved with the Eagle Ford Shale since the very beginning of its production, and is the first company to move Eagle Ford crude oil through pipeline. Curt Anastasio, president and CEO of NuStar Energy LP, noted that NuStar is aggressively expanding its South Texas pipeline network to further increase the delivery of Eagle Ford crude from the field to South Texas refineries where it can be processed, or to South Texas ports where it can then be moved to other markets for refining. As one of the primary midstream providers in the Eagle Ford Shale region, NuStar Energy provides midstream services, including infrastructure, pipeline, storage tanks, breakout facilities, and blending facilities.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Nova Scotia may get LNG export plant
Abstract: Pieridae Energy Canada is proposing to develop $5 billion LNG export facility in Goldboro, Nova Scotia. The proposal includes a liquefaction plant, storage facilities, and marine jetty for loading LNG. The company expects the site to produce 5 million ton/yr of LNG with an onsite storage capacity of 420,000 cu m. Pieridae is negotiating with international energy utilities for the gas. Pieridae expects construction to begin in 2014 with Goldboro LNG operational in late 2018.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Batteries now included
Abstract: As part of the FellowSHIP project, a hybrid energy system is being developed for installation on board the LNG-fuelled supply vessel, Viking Lady. The hybrid energy system consists of an impressive battery pack for energy storage and when installed, the operation of the vessel's engine will be smoother and cost effective giving further emission reductions. The new hybrid energy system for a ship like Viking Lady offers a 20/30% reduction in fuel consumption and CO2 emissions through smoother and more efficient operation of the engines and fuel cell. The reductions of other exhaust components are even higher. Based on these actual costs, the return on investment period for the hybrid system is < 2 yr. New DNV class rules for battery-powered ships have been developed in parallel to this. These are the first class rules developed in order for batteries to be used as part of a vessel's propulsion energy - both as hybrid solutions and for "pure" battery-driven vessels. The project is due for completion in 2013.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy: Modeling and Interpretation
Abstract: The proceedings contain 6 papers. The topics discussed include: dynamic and coverage effects in EIS; interpretation of dielectric properties for materials showing constant-phase-element (CPE) impedance response; multi-sine EIS- drift, non linearity and solution resistance effects; impedance analysis of ion transportation in hierarchical porous core-shell carbons with transmission line model; in situ performance analysis of a high temperature PEM fuel cell stack at loads; and the French SIMCAL research network for modeling of calendar aging for energy storage system in EVs And HEVs - EIS analysis on LFP/C cells.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Special Topics in Battery Science and Technology
Abstract: The proceedings contain 3 papers. The topics discussed include: colloidal manganese oxide nanoparticles as bifunctional catalysts for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions in lithium/air batteries; a multiscale physical model of electrochemical energy storage devices; and recent progress in garnet-type structure solid Li ion electrolytes: Composition - structure - ionic conductivity relationship and chemical stability focused.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Large Scale Electrical Energy Storage 1
Abstract: The proceedings contain 3 papers. The topics discussed include: economic operational planning of grid-connected battery energy storage; performance evaluation of microporous separator in Fe/V redox flow battery; and spectroscopic study of vanadium electrolytes in vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB).

Authors: Andersson K., Bhandari K., Chamoun S., Engel K.
Title: Design and evaluation of a concept for storing thermal energy
Source title: NordDesign 2012 - Proceedings of the 9th NordDesign Conference
Affiliations: KTH, School of Industrial Engineering and Management, Dept. of Machine Design
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, K., KTH, School of Industrial Engineering and Management, Dept. of Machine Design; Bhandari, K., KTH, School of Industrial Engineering and Management, Dept. of Machine Design; Chamoun, S., KTH, School of Industrial Engineering and Management, Dept. of Machine Design; Engel, K., KTH, School of Industrial Engineering and Management, Dept. of Machine Design
Abstract: Thermal energy storage technology is a promising power source for peak-power requirements in automotive applications as well as for small-scale combined heat-and-power generation. This paper reports project work made in the MF2004 Machine Design advanced course at KTH and describes the design, realization and experimental testing of a concept for storage of thermal energy. The test results were compared to the theoretical model described in the patent application of a steam buffer [1] as developed by RANOTOR AB [2] in Sigtuna, Sweden. The experimental results proved to be in correspondence with the predicted behaviour, which indicates proof of concept. © 2012 NordDesign.All right reserved.
Author Keywords: Solar energy; Steam buffer; Thermal energy storage; Waste heat recovery
Index Keywords: Cogeneration plants; Heat storage; Machine design; Thermal energy; Automotive applications; Combined heat and power generation; Design and evaluations; Experimental testing; Patent applications; Power sources; Proof of concept; Theoretical modeling; Curricula

Authors: Kovács F.
Title: Ways of decreasing carbon-dioxide emission and its economic characterization [СПОСОБЫ СНИЖЕНИЯ ВЫДЕЛЕНИЯ УГЛЕКИСЛОГО ГАЗА И ИХ ЭКОНОМИЧЕСКОЕ ОБОСНОВАНИЕ]
Affiliations: Institution of Mining and Geotechnical Engineering, University of Miskolc, Pf. 91, Budapest, H-1521, Hungary; Magyar tudósok körútja 2. Q.B321, Budapest, H-1117, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Kovács, F., Institution of Mining and Geotechnical Engineering, University of Miskolc, Pf. 91, Budapest, H-1521, Hungary, Magyar tudósok körútja 2. Q.B321, Budapest, H-1117, Hungary
Abstract: The paper deals with the technological and economic (cost) parameters of the release, capture and storage of the carbon dioxide in the flue gases of fossil fuel (coal, natural gas) fired power plants. It makes comparisons and generalisations through processing a wide range of data quoted from the literature. As the first step, the topicality of the issue is justified by illustrating the role of fossil fuels in the energy supply of the more remote future with forecast data. During the technological development of power plants in the last 50 years, block capacity has increased considerably, 5-8 times, with thermal capacity increasing by 50-60%, as a result of which specific carbon dioxide release has decreased by 30-40%. The paper briefly refers to the theoretical possibility of the sequestration of the carbon dioxide captured from flue gases in geological formations. The enhancing effects of the implementation of CO2 capture on investment costs and its reducing effect on net power plant output and utilization (thermal) efficiency are also analysed in the paper. The efficiency of CO2 capture and the parameters of atmospheric carbon dioxide emission are also given attached to fuel types and technological solutions. As a parameter of the technological solutions, it is indicated what specific cost (USD/tCO2) is demanded for CO2 capture or avoidance, and to what extent it raises the costs of electricity production. © 2012 North Caucasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, State Technological University. All rights reserved.

Authors: Guttman N., BABAR Collaboration
Title: Studies of charmonium states in two-photon fusion at BABAR
Source title: Proceedings of the 47th Rencontres de Moriond - 2012 QCD and High Energy Interactions
Affiliations: Tel Aviv University, Department of High Energy Physics, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Guttman, N., Tel Aviv University, Department of High Energy Physics, Israel; BABAR Collaboration
Abstract: We report on two studies using two-photon fusion events, γγ → J/ψω and γγ → ηcπ+π−, performed on a data sample of around 500 fb−1 collected by the BABAR experiment at the PEP-II asymmetric energy e+e− storage ring at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory at center-of-mass energies at or around the Υ(2S), Υ(3S), and Υ(4S) resonances. © Published by ARISF, 2012
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Asymmetric energy; BABAR experiment; Center-of-mass energies; Charmonium; Data sample; Gammagamma; Two photon; Photons

Authors: Bhatti Z.W., Miniskar N.R., Preuveneers D., Wuyts R., Berbers Y., Catthoor F.
Title: Memory and communication driven spatio-temporal scheduling on MPSoCs
Source title: Proceedings - SBCCI 2012: 25th Symposium on Integrated Circuits and Systems Design
Affiliations: DistriNet, KU Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200A, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium; IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Bhatti, Z.W., DistriNet, KU Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200A, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium; Miniskar, N.R., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium; Preuveneers, D., DistriNet, KU Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200A, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium; Wuyts, R., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium; Berbers, Y., DistriNet, KU Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200A, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium; Catthoor, F., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001, Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Scheduling and executing software efficiently on contemporary embedded systems, featuring heterogeneous multi-processors, multiple power modes, complex memory hierarchies and advanced interconnects, is a daunting task. State-of-the-art tools that schedule software tasks to hardware resources face limitations: (1) either they do not take into account the interdependancies among processing, memory and communica- tion constraints (2) or they decouple the problem of spatial assignment from temporal scheduling. As a result existing tools make sub-optimal spatio-temporal scheduling decisions. This paper presents a technique to find globally optimized solutions by co-exploring spatio-temporal schedules for computation, data storage and communication simultaneously, considering the inter-dependencies between them. Experiments on mapping exploration of an image processing application on a heterogeneous MPSoC platform show that this co-exploration methodology finds schedules that are more energy efficient, when compared to decoupled exploration techniques for the particular application and target platform. ©2012 IEEE.

Authors: Chaari A., Fdhila R., Neji B., Hamdani T.M., Alimi A.M.
Title: PSO based data routing in a networked distributed Pico-satellites system
Source title: Proceedings - 2012 IEEE 1st AESS European Conference on Satellite Telecommunications, ESTEL 2012
Affiliations: REGIM: REsearch Group on Intelligent Machines, University of Sfax, ENIS, BP 1173, 3038 Sfax, Tunisia
Authors with affiliations: Chaari, A., REGIM: REsearch Group on Intelligent Machines, University of Sfax, ENIS, BP 1173, 3038 Sfax, Tunisia; Fdhila, R., REGIM: REsearch Group on Intelligent Machines, University of Sfax, ENIS, BP 1173, 3038 Sfax, Tunisia; Neji, B., REGIM: REsearch Group on Intelligent Machines, University of Sfax, ENIS, BP 1173, 3038 Sfax, Tunisia; Hamdani, T.M., REGIM: REsearch Group on Intelligent Machines, University of Sfax, ENIS, BP 1173, 3038 Sfax, Tunisia; Alimi, A.M., REGIM: REsearch Group on Intelligent Machines, University of Sfax, ENIS, BP 1173, 3038 Sfax, Tunisia
Abstract: Low earth orbit satellites networks are capable of providing wireless connectivity to any part of the world while guaranteeing lower delays and better bit error rate performance. During the last years, there have been many growing interests towards the development of small satellites. Using these miniaturized systems as a cooperating network allows cost saving and a short development period. However, these systems present the drawback of energy management which is the most important problem to care about. Therefore, the optimization of the processing time and the efficient implementation of the information flow and storage on board must be discussed with respect to the quick topology changes. In this paper, we discuss the use of a network of Pico-satellites with distributed tasks instead of one big satellite to get a fault-tolerant and a robust system, this will be helpful for cost saves and development time reducing. Thus, we have to consider an intelligent system able to achieve several space missions such as attitude control, telemetry and communication. So, we present as a first step different routing algorithms used in small satellites and terrestrial networks. In addition, we present the proposed simulation system which is based on satellite position prediction, satellites tracking software and the use of a Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO) as an intelligent technique for information assignment. As a result, the simulation shows the importance of the use of intelligent techniques in space application due to the complicated environment and the lack of energy sources compared to the earth networks. In deed, The PSO solution avoids the use of one satellite in a critical state and generates a good quality of service when big data traffic in the network occurs, that is because of sharing and distributing the whole traffic process. This solution allows the sustainability of the network and a better Quality of service.
Author Keywords: Data routing; Pico satellites network; Position track and determination; PSO; Satellites ground stations networks; Small satellite; Space communication system

Authors: Da Rosa T.R., Larréa V., Calazans N., Moraes F.G.
Title: Power consumption reduction in MPSoCs through DFS
Source title: Proceedings - SBCCI 2012: 25th Symposium on Integrated Circuits and Systems Design
Affiliations: PUCRS, FACIN, Av. Ipiranga 6681, Porto Alegre - 90619-900, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Da Rosa, T.R., PUCRS, FACIN, Av. Ipiranga 6681, Porto Alegre - 90619-900, Brazil; Larréa, V., PUCRS, FACIN, Av. Ipiranga 6681, Porto Alegre - 90619-900, Brazil; Calazans, N., PUCRS, FACIN, Av. Ipiranga 6681, Porto Alegre - 90619-900, Brazil; Moraes, F.G., PUCRS, FACIN, Av. Ipiranga 6681, Porto Alegre - 90619-900, Brazil
Abstract: The use of power management techniques is mandatory in embedded devices, which must provide high performance with low energy consumption. Due to the high variability present in the applications workload executed by these devices, this management should be executed dynamically. The use of traditional dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) techniques proved to be useful in several scenarios to save energy. Nonetheless, due to technology scaling that limits the voltage variation and slow response of the DVFS schemes, the use of such technique may become inadequate. As alternative, the use of dynamic frequency scaling (DFS) may provide a good trade-off between power savings and power overhead. This paper proposes a distributed DFS scheme for NoC-based MPSoCs. Both NoC and PEs have an individual controlling scheme. The DFS scheme for PEs takes into account its computation and communication load to dynamically change the operating frequency. In the NoC, the DFS controller uses packet information to decide the router operating frequency. Real and synthetic applications were used to evaluate the proposed scheme. Results show that the number of executed instructions is reduced up to 41%, with an execution time overhead up to 18%. The power dissipation is reduced in PEs up to 26% and in the NoC up to 76%. ©2012 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DFS; MPSoC; NoC; Power management
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Dynamic frequency scaling; Economic and social effects; Electric power utilization; Energy utilization; Multiprocessing systems; Power management; Routers; Systems analysis; Voltage scaling; Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling; Executed instructions; Low energy consumption; MPSoC; Operating frequency; Power consumption reduction; Power management techniques; Synthetic application; Network-on-chip

Title: Materials for Energy Conversion and Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 69 papers. The topics discussed include: microstructure modification of NiO/YSZ anode in solid oxide fuel cell by particle size gradation of YSZ; preparation and properties of polyamide 6-functionalized nanometer-sized graphene composite fiber; 'window' effect in the analysis of universal dynamic response; preparation and characterization of polymer electrolyte based on comb-shaped poly(oxyethylene) with ether side chains; study on multi-doped ceria-based solid electrolytes; ferroelectric-to-ferroelectric phase transition induced electro-caloric energy conversion in barium titanate at room temperature; synthesis and properties of microencapsulated solid paraffin phase change materials; the parameter estimate method to determine the optimal thickness for DSSC electrode; technology of polyphenylene sulfide (PPS) resin/graphite conductive composite for bipolar plate; and influence of heat treatment on the properties of CuInS2 sensitized solar cells.

Authors: Barbosa F.C.
Title: Hybrid transit bus technology assessment - A feasibility approach
Affiliations: FCB Consulting, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Barbosa, F.C., FCB Consulting, Brazil
Abstract: Stricter environmental regulation and the increasing concern about fuel economy and emissions have driven transit agencies and operators toward environmental and economic concerns when selecting transit bus technology. In this scenario, hybrid bus, that combines two or more distinct propulsion systems (generally combustion engine and electric motor), has been seen as a choice that balances both the need for better environmental and efficiency performance and capital expenditures for introducing new technology based transit bus fleets. The source of better performance of hybrid buses is the ability to i) optimize the operating point of combustion engine to achieve best fuel economy; ii) store energy generated during braking at storage devices (batteries, supercapacitors or flywheels), to be used to power the vehicle when needed, and, hence, iii) downsizing engine due to reduced average power requirements. Most significant gains in efficiency and environmental performance of hybrid vehicles are achieved during starting and stopping regimes, what makes them suitable to be used in congested areas, typical of transit routes. Regarding system design, three main architectures can be used for commercial vehicles: i) serial hybrid, in which combustion engine has no mechanical connection to the driving gear, with the vehicle being driven solely by an electric motor; ii) parallel hybrid, in which the combustion engine and electric motor are both mechanically connected to the wheels, a configuration suitable to less congested regimes, where combustion engine can be tuned to work in its most efficient range; and iii) dual hybrid, in which an engine and two electric motors, with complex planetary gear arrangements, make possible a continuously variable transmission through two parallel routes: electrical and mechanical. This complex design provides freedom in managing engine speed and torque versus vehicle speed and power demand. On a cost perspective, the "Achilles Heel" of hybrid technology, much has to be done, since costs of energy storage devices and electronic components still remain an issue in near and medium term. In transit application, however, since intensive use maximizes hybrid benefits over traditional bus configuration, the expectation is that regulatory measures, like correctly pricing diesel fuel and incentives to hybrid fleets at early market introduction, can make the technology competitive and economically viable. Brazil, one of the largest transit bus markets, is debuting this technology, with some on going field trials and an announcement of a hybrid bus fleet in the city of Curitiba, State of Paraná, with an order of 60 local made hybrid buses for delivery expected from 2012. This study presents the state of art hybrid bus technologies available worldwide, and, whenever possible, their operational results, with a special focus on Brazilian market, its structure and policies available to make this technology come true. Copyright © 2012 SAE International.

Authors: Rudge A., Guilherme R.
Title: Simulation of the fuel consumption reduction potential of a mild hybrid system applied to a popular flexible fuel vehicle
Affiliations: Volkswagen do Brasil, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Rudge, A., Volkswagen do Brasil, Brazil; Guilherme, R., Volkswagen do Brasil, Brazil
Abstract: Fuel consumption and CO2 emission are important drivers of automotive industry product evolution. In Europe, the manufactures have the compromise to reduce their fleet consumption steadily and, in Brazil, a still voluntary but growing labeling program makes the vehicular energetic efficiency one of the main concerns during the concept phase. Different from the full hybrid technology, where the car can be driven purely by the electric motor, the mild hybrid has been mentioned in literature as cost-effective route to reduce CO2 emissions through the combination of a highly responsive low power electric motor, which acts supporting the internal combustion engine in special driving situations, with energy recovery and storage system composed of advanced batteries. Therefore the mild hybrid system can be understood as one type of downsizing strategy. In Brazil the tax reduction policy for 1.0 vehicle makes this strategy attractive to improve vehicular performance and reduce fuel consumption. The objective of this work was therefore the evaluation via simulation software of the potential of this technology applied on a typical popular vehicle in terms of performance and fuel consumption and CO2 emission reduction. Copyright © 2012 SAE International.

Authors: Berdja M., Abbad B., Laidi M., Yahi F., Ouali M.
Title: Numerical simulation of a phase change material (PCM) in a domestic refrigerator powered by photovoltaic energy
Source title: International Symposium on Advances in Computational Heat Transfer
Affiliations: Unité de développement des équipements solaires, (UDES), N°11, BP386, Bou-Ismail, Tipaza  42415, Algeria
Authors with affiliations: Berdja, M., Unité de développement des équipements solaires, (UDES), N°11, BP386, Bou-Ismail, Tipaza  42415, Algeria; Abbad, B., Unité de développement des équipements solaires, (UDES), N°11, BP386, Bou-Ismail, Tipaza  42415, Algeria; Laidi, M., Unité de développement des équipements solaires, (UDES), N°11, BP386, Bou-Ismail, Tipaza  42415, Algeria; Yahi, F., Unité de développement des équipements solaires, (UDES), N°11, BP386, Bou-Ismail, Tipaza  42415, Algeria; Ouali, M., Unité de développement des équipements solaires, (UDES), N°11, BP386, Bou-Ismail, Tipaza  42415, Algeria
Abstract: We present in this work the results of a numerical simulation of a phase change material (PCM) used as a storage device in a domestic vapor compression refrigerator powered by photovoltaic energy. The phase change material is a eutectic solution. The PCM permits to keep the refrigerator compartment temperature quasi constant during the extended shutdown of the compressor. We use the finite volume method (FVM) as a numerical approach to address the conservation equations. The Phase change is simulated using the enthalpy method. Our goal is to simulate-through a mathematical modeling of the phase change Kinetics phenomena in the PCM-the operating regime of the refrigerator. The model validity will be provided by the consistency of the numerical solution of the solidification phenomena, with the experimental results obtained in the laboratory. This comparison is made according to the start and the switch off sequences of the compressor, controlled by the temperature at the thermostat, which is located on the lateral side of the aluminum shell containing the PCM. The use of a PCM is a way of decreasing the cost of the photovoltaic systems by opting for a thermal storage cooling instead of electric storage batteries. It is also a way of minimizing the electrical consumption by reducing the operating time of the compressor. © 2012, Begell House Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: White W.A.
Title: Biosequestration and Ecological Diversity: Mitigating and Adapting to Climate Change and Environmental Degradation
Source title: Biosequestration and Ecological Diversity: Mitigating and Adapting to Climate Change and Environmental Degradation
Authors with affiliations: White, W.A.
Abstract: Increased throughput of carbon-based fossil energy, the destruction of Earth’s forests, and other land use changes have resulted in ever higher levels of waste in the form of greenhouse gases—as well as a diminished capacity of the planet to absorb and store those wastes. This means that to avoid catastrophic global warming and maintain the habitability of Earth by protecting essential soil and water resources, we will need to not only reduce emissions, but also increase carbon storage in the land system. Biosequestration and Ecological Diversity: Mitigating and Adapting to Climate Change and Environmental Degradation discusses ways to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere and build soil by changing the way people use and manage land. Principles and Practices for Better Land Management Examining biosequestration in social, economic, and political context, the book reviews recent scientific evidence on climate change and global ecological degradation and explains how the carbon cycle has been transformed by destructive land use practices, such as deforestation and the burning of fossil fuels. It describes the principles of biosequestration and restorative land management practices and discusses the potential of carbon storage. The author offers specific examples of inexpensive, proven practices that build soil, protect scarce water resources, and enhance ecological diversity. He also identifies conservation policies that provide technical assistance and financial resources for ecological protection and restoration. How You Can Help Mitigate Climate Change with a Little Piece of Land Restorative land use and land management practices are critical components of any comprehensive strategy for mitigating and adapting to climate change and global environmental degradation. This book explains how anyone who owns or manages land—from an apartment to a city lot to a farm, forest, park, or even a golf course—can help protect and enhance the biological sequestration of carbon. © 2013 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Miqdam Tariq C., Khalil I.A., Kazem H.A., Hasoon F., Aljibori H.S.S., Alwaeli A.A.K., Raheem F.S., Alwaeli A.H.A.
Title: Effect of design variation on saved energy of concentrating solar power prototype
Source title: Lecture Notes in Engineering and Computer Science
Affiliations: Machines and Equipments Eng. Dept., University of Technology, Baghdad, Iraq; Faculty of Engineering, Sohar University, Sohar, Oman; College of Applied Science, Sohar, Oman; Education College Ibn Rushed, University of Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Miqdam Tariq, C., Machines and Equipments Eng. Dept., University of Technology, Baghdad, Iraq; Khalil, I.A., Machines and Equipments Eng. Dept., University of Technology, Baghdad, Iraq; Kazem, H.A., Faculty of Engineering, Sohar University, Sohar, Oman; Hasoon, F., Faculty of Engineering, Sohar University, Sohar, Oman; Aljibori, H.S.S., College of Applied Science, Sohar, Oman; Alwaeli, A.A.K., Education College Ibn Rushed, University of Baghdad, Iraq; Raheem, F.S., Education College Ibn Rushed, University of Baghdad, Iraq; Alwaeli, A.H.A., Faculty of Engineering, Sohar University, Sohar, Oman
Abstract: The sun is a huge emission of energy. Mainly of the energy is in the form of heat and light, which can be collected and used for generating electricity, as well as for heating, cooling and lighting building. Electric utility companies are using mirrors to concentrate heat from the sun to produce environmentally friendly electricity for cities. This abundance of solar energy makes Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) plants an attractive alternative to traditional power plants, which burn polluting fossil fuels such as oil and coal. Unlike traditional power plants, CSP systems provide an environmentally kind source of energy, produce virtually no emissions, and consume no fuel other than sunlight. This study is focused on the feasibility of improving CSP planet efficiency, by design and investigates a diminished prototype. Three cases studies have been investigated these are, coloring the central receiver with selective black color, enclose the receiver by a glass box and color the glass enclosed by specific black color. Investigations have been conducted in Baghdad-Iraq summertime weathers 2011. The results showed a good improvement in thermal storage when using the glass enclosed comparison with other two cases. Also, it is found that this improvement varied and depends on month and reaches the peak in summer. © 2012 Newswood Limited. All rights reserved.

Authors: Stylianopoulos C.
Title: Carbohydrates: Regulation of Metabolism
Affiliations: Biostatistics Consulting Services, Veria, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Stylianopoulos, C., Biostatistics Consulting Services, Veria, Greece
Abstract: The most important simple carbohydrates in human metabolism are glucose, fructose, and galactose. Most carbohydrates have to be converted to glucose in order to be utilized for energy production. Glucose is the circulating form of carbohydrate in the bloodstream and consists of the largest quantity of absorbed carbohydrate. Appropriate regulation of glucose metabolism is essential for health and survival. Glucose metabolism is subject to hormonal regulation, allosteric enzyme control, and regulation of gene expression. Diseases of carbohydrate metabolism include carbohydrate malabsorption, glycogen storage diseases, and diabetes mellitus. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Haubert T., Mindl P.
Title: DC/DC power converter for super-capacitor supplied by electric power splitter
Affiliations: Czech Technical University, Prague, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Haubert, T., Czech Technical University, Prague, Czech Republic; Mindl, P., Czech Technical University, Prague, Czech Republic
Abstract: The aim of the article is design of DC/DC converter and discussing of problematic supply using electric power splitter. The electric power splitter with AC/DC converter is source for the DC/DC converter, which is dedicated for charging and discharging of hybrid car drive super-capacitor energy storage. The electric power splitter is synchronous machine with two rotating parts. First rotor contains permanent magnet and the second rotor contains three-phase windings. The amplitude of output voltage depends on difference between first and second rotor speed. The main role of the DC/DC converter is to optimize energy content in super-capacitor storage used to acceleration and deceleration driving period of the passenger car with hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) drive system using electric power splitter. © Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht 2012.
